newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania cen.bank lifts one-week rate to 65 pct.
newsitem.headline: Romania cen.bank lifts one-week rate to 65 pct.

text.p: Romania's central bank (BNR) said on Thursday it jacked up the minimum permitted rate for its one-week refinancing funds by eight percentage points, to 65 percent, stepping up its drive to tighten monetary policy.
The move follows a four percentage point rise in the rate to 57 percent last week and a hike in the central bank's discount rate to 50 percent earlier this month from 35 percent.
The BNR's tightened monetary policy is aimed at calming quickening inflation, also in line with International Monetary Fund recommendations.
Year-on-year inflation rose to 47.4 percent last November from October's 45.1 percent, sharply exceeding the 20 percent target agreed with the Fund for 1996.
Inflation is expected to climb after Romania's new centrist government doubled fuel prices earlier this month.
The Fund suspended a three-year standby credit of $460 million after criticising what were considered lax policies of the leftist government toppled in November's general election.
The central bank reduced its refinancing funds at Thursday's auction to 1.1 trillion lei from a previous 2.15 trillion lei.

An IMF mission is expected to start talks in Bucharest on Thursday on a new loan accord with the centrist coalition cabinet headed by Prime Minister Victor Ciorbea. -- Mirela Eremia, Bucharest Newsroom 40-1 3120264
